newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian shares close higher, outlook quiet.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian shares close higher, outlook quiet.

text.p: Equities closed up again on Friday at the Nigerian stock market after an initial rally on Thursday, but traders said business would still be low in the coming week.
The all-share index ended at 8569.78 from 8566.78 on Thursday when it strengthened slightly.
Analysts said trading activity was still low as reflected in in a shorter than normal session on the Lagos floor on Friday.
"People wanted to sell shares but there were no buyers," said one, attributing the trend to lack of funds.
Traders say the money market was beginning to attract funds from stocks.
Brewing and cement firms were the main losers, falling on continuous dumping of their shares, traders said.
Nigerian Breweries eased to 19.60 naira, down 20 kobo, while Guinness was down 10 kobo at 7.00 naira.
West African Portland Cement Company (WAPCO) and sister-company Ashaka Cement were both 10 kobo down, respectively at 64.50 naira and 13.00 naira.
Healthcare firm Smithkline Beecham ended weaker too, at 6.00 naira, down 30 kobo.
Strong finishers were few, led by Nigerian Flour Mills, which is rising on the expectation of improved results. It closed 15 kobo more at 17.00 naira.
An oil miller P.S. Mandrides shot up 20 kobo on the strength of its recent good performances, closing at 5.90 naira.
But Nestle, the current hottest stock on the market, was steady on Friday at 45.55 naira.
Petroleum shares, until displaced by Nestle recently as the toast of the market, were also relatively quiet. Only Agip saw a change, sliding 20 kobo to 20.60 naira.
